citations.narrative:
The facility houses two Ring-Tailed Lemurs and does not have a continuous perimeter fence that meets the requirements.
The perimeter fence is approximately 4 1/2 feet tall whereas a perimeter fence for Ring-Tailed Lemurs must be at least 6
feet tall. The perimeter fence also does not restrict animals or unauthorized persons from going through it or under it. A
perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized persons and animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a
secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. An outdoor housing facility must be
enclosed by a fence that is of sufficient height to keep unwanted species out. Fences less than 6 feet high must be
approved by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects nonhuman primates by restricting
unauthorized humans, and animals the size of dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going through it or under it and having
contact with the nonhuman primates. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside wall or fence of the primary
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and outside the perimeter fence. Such fences
less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved by the administrator. Correct by ensuring that all
species requiring a perimeter fence are completely enclosed within an adequate perimeter fence that meets all
requirements. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing and sent to the APHIS Administrator. Correct by 12-
AUG-2024.

An enclosure housing 8 juvenile bison has an area of fencing that is in disrepair. An accident involving a vehicle hitting the
fence caused a bent/broken support post that has shifted the fencing to angle inward. The fence is approximately 4 feet
above the ground in this area. Failure to maintain primary enclosure fencing can result in animal escape and create areas
where animals can be injured. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for
the animals involved. Correct by ensuring that housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and contain the animals securely. Correct by 26-JULY-2024.

The facility houses a Giraffe and does not have a continuous perimeter fence that meets the requirements. The perimeter
fence is approximately 4 1/2 feet tall whereas perimeter fence regulations require the perimeter fence for a Giraffe to be at
least 8 feet tall. The perimeter fence also does not restrict animals or unauthorized persons from going through it or under
it. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized persons and animals. A perimeter fence also acts as
a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. All outdoor housing facilities must be
enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized person out. Fences less than 8
feet high for potentially dangerous animals, such as but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars,
etc.), bears, wolves, rhinoceros, and elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by
the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the
outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or
persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be
approved in writing by the Administrator. Correct by ensuring that all species requiring a perimeter fence are completely
enclosed within an adequate perimeter fence that meets all requirements. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in
writing and sent to the APHIS Administrator. Correct by 12-OCT-2024.

A primary enclosure housing 200 budgerigars is not protecting them from injury:
• The enclosure contains a fan that many of the birds use as a perch. The fan has a wire blade guard attached. However,
the small birds housed in the enclosure could still be injured by the fan blades if their tail feathers or wings were to fit
through the blade guards.
• The enclosure contains two exposed electrical cords in the enclosure that is accessible to the birds. The first is located
adjacent to a window. The second is the electrical cord for the fan which has a section approximately 4 inches in length
that is missing a protective covering.
• The enclosure contains several exposed electrical outlets including one that powers the fan, one adjacent to a window,
and another adjacent to a mounted thermometer.
There are no solid barriers to prevent the birds from potentially having direct contact with the fan, electrical cords, or
electrical outlets. Equipment within primary enclosures that is not designed and/or utilized in a safe manner could cause
injury or death to the animals. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are
structurally sound. The primary enclosures must be kept in good repair. Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures are
constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury. Correct by 26-JULY-2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.78(d) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The facility houses two Ring-Tailed Lemurs and does not have a continuous perimeter fence that meets the requirements. 
The perimeter fence is approximately 4 1/2 feet tall whereas a perimeter fence for Ring-Tailed Lemurs must be at least 6 
feet tall. The perimeter fence also does not restrict animals or unauthorized persons from going through it or under it. A 
perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized persons and animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a 
secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. An outdoor housing facility must be 
enclosed by a fence that is of sufficient height to keep unwanted species out. Fences less than 6 feet high must be 
approved by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects nonhuman primates by restricting 
unauthorized humans, and animals the size of dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going through it or under it and having 
contact with the nonhuman primates. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside wall or fence of the primary 
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and outside the perimeter fence. Such fences 
less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved by the administrator. Correct by ensuring that all 
species requiring a perimeter fence are completely enclosed within an adequate perimeter fence that meets all 
requirements. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing and sent to the APHIS Administrator. Correct by 12-
AUG-2024. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An enclosure housing 8 juvenile bison has an area of fencing that is in disrepair. An accident involving a vehicle hitting the 
fence caused a bent/broken support post that has shifted the fencing to angle inward. The fence is approximately 4 feet 
above the ground in this area. Failure to maintain primary enclosure fencing can result in animal escape and create areas 
where animals can be injured. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for 
the animals involved. Correct by ensuring that housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to 
protect the animals from injury and contain the animals securely. Correct by 26-JULY-2024. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility houses a Giraffe and does not have a continuous perimeter fence that meets the requirements. The perimeter 
fence is approximately 4 1/2 feet tall whereas perimeter fence regulations require the perimeter fence for a Giraffe to be at

least 8 feet tall. The perimeter fence also does not restrict animals or unauthorized persons from going through it or under 
it. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized persons and animals. A perimeter fence also acts as 
a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. All outdoor housing facilities must be 
enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized person out. Fences less than 8 
feet high for potentially dangerous animals, such as but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, 
etc.), bears, wolves, rhinoceros, and elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by 
the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and 
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can 
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the 
outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or 
persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be 
approved in writing by the Administrator. Correct by ensuring that all species requiring a perimeter fence are completely 
enclosed within an adequate perimeter fence that meets all requirements. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in 
writing and sent to the APHIS Administrator. Correct by 12-OCT-2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A primary enclosure housing 200 budgerigars is not protecting them from injury: 
• The enclosure contains a fan that many of the birds use as a perch. The fan has a wire blade guard attached. However, 
the small birds housed in the enclosure could still be injured by the fan blades if their tail feathers or wings were to fit 
through the blade guards.  
• The enclosure contains two exposed electrical cords in the enclosure that is accessible to the birds. The first is located 
adjacent to a window. The second is the electrical cord for the fan which has a section approximately 4 inches in length 
that is missing a protective covering.  
• The enclosure contains several exposed electrical outlets including one that powers the fan, one adjacent to a window, 
and another adjacent to a mounted thermometer. 
 
There are no solid barriers to prevent the birds from potentially having direct contact with the fan, electrical cords, or 
electrical outlets. Equipment within primary enclosures that is not designed and/or utilized in a safe manner could cause 
injury or death to the animals. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are 
structurally sound. The primary enclosures must be kept in good repair. Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures are 
constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury. Correct by 26-JULY-2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
